questions.text: Osteopetrosis is a congenital metabolic bone disease caused by defective osteoclastic resorption of the immature bone that presents with an increased frequency of long bone fractures, cranial nerve palsies, and low back pain. Which of the following most accurately describes the cause of osteopetrosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased mineralisation of the osteoid matrix

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased expression of type I collagen

options.label: C
options.text: Loss-of-function of carbonic anhydrase II gene

questions.correct_answer: C. Loss-of-function of carbonic anhydrase II gene
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Loss-of-function of carbonic anhydrase II gene Osteopetrosis. It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative and/or qualitative defects in type I collagen formation , one of the major components of fibrillar connective tissue in skin, ligaments, bones, sclera, and teeth. Either there is a reduction in type I collagen, or it is replaced with poorly functioning mutant collagen.

Highyeild:

Osteopetrosis is characterised by defective osteoclastic resorption of immature bone caused by a loss of function mutation in the carbonic anhydrase II gene. Carbonic anhydrase II is an enzyme that converts carbon dioxide and water into H+ and bicarbonate. The protons created are then transported across the ruffled border of osteoclasts, leading to acidification and demineralisation of the bone matrix. There are AD and AR forms of osteopetrosis, with the AR form usually being fatal in the first few years of life. Measurement of his erythrocyte carbonic anhydrase activity revealed a deficiency of CA II. incorrect options: HYP Osteoporosis vs osteomalacia: Osteoporosis is a condition of quantitative decrease in bone mass. (Not qualitative like in osteomalacia where the ratio of unmineralized bone matrix to bone mass is increased, making it a qualitative defect) Etiology: Causes: These are multiple etiological factors responsible for osteoporosis a. Age Related b. Post menopausal c. Lifestyle factors · Alcohol abuse · High salt intake · Low calcium intake · Vitamin D insufficiency · Smoking (active and passive) · Bed ridden patient (Immobilization) d. Hypogonadal states like · Androgen insensitivity · Hyperprolactinemia · Premature menopause e. Endocrine disorder · Adrenal insufficiency · Cushing's syndrome · Diabetes mellitus types 1 and 2 · Hyperparathyroidism · Thyrotoxicosis f. Gastrointestinal disorder · Celiac disease · Inflammatory bowel diseases · Malabsorption g. Hematologic disorders · Multiple myeloma · Sickle cell diseases · Thalassemia h. Rheumatologic and autoimmune diseases · Ankylosing spondylitis · Rheumatoid arthritis i. Medications · Aluminum (in antacids) · Glucocorticoids (>5 mg/d) · Anticoagulants (heparin)) · Prednisone or equivalent for >3 months · Anticonvulsants · Methotrexate Clinical Features: Osteoporosis usually manifest as pain and reason for pain in most cases is a fracture which may be there with a trivial trauma, Usual sites involved in fracture are vertebra, hip (fracture neck of femur) and distal radius (colles fracture). With growing age (old age) the patients (more commonly female) may develop as kyphotic deformity known as dowager's hump.

Osteogenesis imperfecta is associated with a decrease in type I collagen (COL1A1 and COL1A2 genes). Option: D. Achondroplasia is associated with a mutation of FGFR3 (fibroblast growth factor receptor 3, on chromosome 4P)

questions.text: A 36-year-old female slipped at home and sustained a distal radius fracture. A junior resident in ortho emergency noticed abnormal bone appearance on the radiographs and referred her for a skeletal survey and further evaluation. Pelvis and spine radiographs are provided here. What is the etiology of this disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Inability of proximal tubules to reabsorb phosphate

options.label: B
options.text: Autosomal dominant inheritance of altered fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3)

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Defective osteoclast function Osteopetrosis. It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative and/or qualitative defects in type I collagen formation, one of the major components of fibrillar connective tissue in skin, ligaments, bones, sclera, and teeth. Either there is a reduction in type I collagen, or it is replaced with poorly functioning mutant collagen.

Highyeild:

Osteopetrosis/Marble Bone Disease/Albert Schonberg Disease It is also a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. The bone contained an increased number of osteoclasts, but these don't resorb bone, as evidenced by the absence of ruffled borders & clear zones, and are unable to respond to PTH. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persist down into metaphysis and diaphysis, causing osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones. Inheritance depends on the form of the disease: Malignant osteopetrosis (congenital form) is autosomal recessive Osteopetrosis tarda (adolescence /adult form) is Autosomal dominant. Radiological features: Sclerotic X-Rays known as Marble bone diseases Expansion of proximal and distal ends of long bone known as Erlenmeyer flask deformity Spine can show sclerosis adjacent to end plate known as Rugger Jersey Spine

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Inability of proximal tubules to reabsorb phosphate: describes familial hypophosphatemic rickets. Option: B. Autosomal dominant inheritance of altered fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3): describes Achondroplasia. Option: C. Defect in renal 25-(OH)-vitamin D1 alpha-hydroxylase: describes Type I hereditary Rickets

questions.text: A 72-year-old female was operated on for an insufficiency fracture of the left hip 2 days back. Intraoperatively her bones were found to be very weak. Her DEXA T score was -3.3. Her Orthopaedician started her on a drug that has direct anabolic effects on the bone to increase her bone mass. What drug did her orthopaedician give her?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intermittent PTH Injections Osteoblasts are primary targets for PTH. Once activated, they secrete RANKL and IL-6 , which causes osteoclast proliferation/maturation and increases bone resorption . Because of this coupled remodeling process, several observations have been made: 1) intermittent PTH injections increase bone mass, 2) continuous infusion leads to bone resorption , and 3) dosing should not continue past 2 yrs .

A viral infection is also a causative factor for development of Paget's disease in people who have these genes. S/SX The majority of patients have no symptoms and many individuals are unaware that they have the disease until it is discovered when the patient is being examined for other reasons. Pain arising from the affected bone is the commonest symptom and bones that support body weight may deform into a bowed or bent shape.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2,3,5 The clinical presentation is consistent with osteopetrosis (Marble Bone Disease). Osteopetrosis is associated with long bone fractures, osteomyelitis, cranial nerve palsies, and coxa vara. Osteopetrosis is not associated with vertebral compression fractures.
